title: Will negotiations on the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) be completed in 2016?
preds: What looked promising at the beginning of the year proved too much for the RECP negotiators.
All bets are off in trade talk due to American election campaign.
The RCEP’s potential future as a major trade bloc will remain uncertain until there is enough political will to go through the arduous negotiation rounds.

Joint statement no longer even has a deadline, not even for next year.
https://dfat.gov.au/trade/agreements/rcep/news/Documents/rcep-joint-leaders-statement-8-september-2016.pdf

An announcement was made early in September that because of the need for continued negotiations, the timeline has been extended to wrap up the talks to October 2017, just prior to ASEAN's 2017 summit.

http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/1080409/rcep-leaders-to-skip-2016-completion-target - "However, the talks have not made much progress so far, and discussion on details has not begun. With only three months left in 2016, it does not seem realistic to expect that the RCEP will be able to close a deal, and negotiators will probably need another year to continue talks, experts have said."
India up for tough fight at RCEP
Dead in the water for this year.
In their last meeting in Laos, ministers agreed to drop the end 2016 target.

Dropping from 5% to 1%. New deadline is October 2017.
http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/1083892/rcep-aims-for-pact-in-13-months
http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/RCEP-talks-extended-to-next-year-amid-hiccups-30295062.html
Leaders have officially shelved plans to get the agreement done this year. http://www.bangkokpost.com/business/news/1080409/rcep-leaders-to-skip-2016-completion-target
The negotiations for the proposed mega trade deal - RCEP - would miss the deadline of concluding the talks by December this year, Commerce and Industry Minister Nirmala Sitharaman said today.

Everybody is (a) very busy with other matters just now and (b) unless they are China, rather concerned about how the PRC has been behaving of late.  This has been promoted to the back burner, where it can do relatively little damage to anyone for a while.
Down from 40 just a few days ago as the result of http://www.thehindu.com/business/Economy/rcep-negotiations-may-miss-december-deadline/article9026863.ece
Waiting to see results of latest negotiations.

I've yet to see any comprehensive report of the negotiating round concluded last week in Ho Chi Minh City, but so far the deadline remains "end of 2016". I'm going down from 45% due to absence of any positive news, but still think there's a good chance of some sort of conclusion this year.

India changes tack on RCEP negotiations (+1)
http://wtocenter.vn/news/india-changes-tack-rcep-negotiations

With India showing flexibility, though, the RCEP agreement is likely to take shape by the next ministerial conference in November, officials said. "We will try to minimise the differences before November," the second official added. 
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/india-ready-to-abolish-tariff-structure-if-rcep-promises-fdi/articleshow/53626290.cms

US move to "America First" improves long term prospects.
Current issues: 
-Japan prefers TPP.
-China, JP and SK relations
-SCS issues: China, ASEAN, Australia
 http://www.globaltimes.cn/content/999677.shtml

"China will support ASEAN's centrality in pushing forward the conclusion of negotiations for the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP) by the end of this year"
http://english.chinamil.com.cn/news-channels/today-headlines/2016-08/05/content_7192991.htm

Trade ministers of 16 countries, including India, China and Japan will meet tomorrow in Laos to review the progress and resolve issues holding back negotiations of the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership (RCEP).
http://www.bilaterals.org/?rcep-trade-ministers-to-meet-tmrw
Given the ongoing serious disputes about tariffs, investor protection, service liberalization doesn't seem possible.

"RCEP negotiations missed their initial deadline at the end of 2015. There is a high probability that a second deadline will be missed this year. Little up-to-date information on RCEP has been disclosed, making the agreement seem more and more like a black box. More importantly, the negotiation process and the ambition of RCEP’s clauses appear to be far from satisfactory."
http://www.eastasiaforum.org/2016/08/02/three-relationships-for-rcep-members-to-ponder/
Still optimistic but all recent news has been of stalled negotiations and bosses with the authority to negotiate not actually being present.
Initial offers for goods will soon be finalized.
Reducing from 55%. There is still much to do but quite a few more meetings scheduled.

"62% of the companies surveyed predict that TPP will be ratified within the next three years, and close to 95% see the Partnership ratified within five. Almost 44% believe RCEP will become operational within three years, and around 97% within five;"
http://www.asiatoday.com.au/content/huge-opportunity-asean-regional-initiatives-kick-says-new-report
Earlier estimates appear to be overly optimistic, moderate expectations needed
Trade agreements in general have taken a hit with Brexit.
Trade deals are way down in public opinion

Reducing from 67% last month. The negotiation round in New Zealand concluded last week, and so far I haven't seen any positive reports - one originated by Reuters from Wellington cited by @lindsey leads off with "A raft of thorny issues including market access and trade barriers makes it very unlikely that 16 Asia-Pacific countries can hammer out a proposed economic “partnership” by the end of 2016." http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/bid-to-get-a-china-backed-asia-trade-pact-in-2016-seen-failing-short-2858452/

News out of Auckland isn't promising. Nothing of real substance decided and only one more round of discussions this year. (Laos in September) The major obstacle - which has seen talks drag on for three years already - is that there are simply too many stakeholders with disparate needs and desires. Perhaps some sort of agreement can be reached behind closed doors, but these multilateral conferences seem doomed to stagnate.
Press out of the Auckland meeting is not good: http://indianexpress.com/article/world/world-news/bid-to-get-a-china-backed-asia-trade-pact-in-2016-seen-failing-short-2858452/
Possible draft agreement for the ASEAN meeting in September  http://www.nationmultimedia.com/business/Asean-to-force-the-pace-in-RCEP-negotiations-30288000.html
Gotta be more pessimistic than the crowd on this bureaucratic and political hot potato :)

It is practically an iron law of trade agreements that when negotiations are "almost complete," they can stay that way for a real long time.  Those last few details are always put off because they affect highly influential special interest groups within one or more polities whose interests are just about diametrically opposed to everyone else's, including their own governments'.   This one could still get done in '16, though.

The "consensus" has dropped sharply from 72% a month ago to 47% today, though I can't see why. Formal negotiations are set to continue for another two rounds in June and September, and there was a proposal from India a couple of months ago to have informal meetings in between to tackle sticking points. India is always a tough negotiator but I get the impression it wants this agreement even though there is some domestic opposition.

While it is true that negotiators passed the TPP, that does not guarantee legislative confirmation. So, I'm not sure that TPP's status is putting that much pressure on RCEP. I still believe there are unspoken issues related to South China Sea territorial conflicts that is causing some countries to slow-walk this agreement. Then, of course, there are the details themselves that need resolution such as whether there will be an ISDS (investor-state dispute settlement) mechanism.
So, nothing happened in Perth. Nothing becomes the likely result.
This looks like it could take quite a while! Very little of substance has been negotiated yet and the politicians still have to get involved.

RCEP (negotiations) is anticipated to be completed between June and latter in the Fall.   The (completion) negotiations in various rounds (of which we have not reached the last) for purposes of the IFP will be the sole criteria.   Ratification in Congress, Houses of Parliament and other institutional arrangement across the range of countries included in the trade agreement, is not a necessary or sufficient requirement.
China may wish to push this along in order to provide some contrast with how expeditiously they do things, compared to how slowly the TTP is getting ratified, if indeed it will at all.
feeling a lot less optimistic after reading http://www.thehindubusinessline.com/companies/india-will-not-yield-on-services-at-rcep-trade-talks/article8544298.ece

I'm finding virtually no news on the Perth round, though one article has referenced "early next year" as the end of negotiations. Not reading too much into one article, but will drop from 42% to 40%.
 http://www.afr.com/news/economy/trade/blockbuster-asian-trade-deal-embraces-china-rivals-usled-tpp-20160426-gof5jk

Lowering  a bit. A lot of "other" political confrontations generated by China's belligerent South China Sea actions may be pushing against this IFP resolution by 12/31/2016. Included in this prediction, is the heavy handedness China is using to push other ASEAN countries around by sweet economic offers, and thereby split the ASEAN community, yet so transparently played, that everybody know its effectively a bribe to the takers, and a snub to all their other "partners" who are being thrown under the big, red bus. Blowback could be resistance to a full RCEP deal.
RCEP members, it is rumored, want to close the deal mid summer ....
Reducing after reading articles @Khalid linked.  Meeting is this week - need to check back in shortly on this.

Reducing from my forecast of 70% dated 22 March. The 12th round of negotiations is taking place in Perth this week. Will revisit after reading reports of this round of talks, but the two links below suggest that some serious discussions are likely.
with increasing aggression of china, econ partnerships with the west are as close to military alliance as it gets, certainly more important than mere military pacts

The success of the upcoming round of talks in Perth, Australia, will provide a clear and precise indication of progress (non) in its timetable.   If success is achieved, the next round will move to the ASEAN Economic Ministers Forum retreat in May.

I would start high on this question as the 'final' session is scheduled for September, which leaves some time for last minute rounds to iron out the wrinkles. The recently concluded TPP also puts pressure on the non-TPP countries to see the process through so as not to be left behind. Recent doldrums for world trade will also act as a push to get the deal done. Since ratification is not needed, it should be possible to get an agreement in place.

1.China wants to conclude RCEP trade talks this year 
2.India marks big shift in trade policy

Reading events of the 11th meeting seems to be going well. Two more rounds of meetings scheduled for April and June. Which still leaves the head's of state half a year to dot the i's and cross the t's.
I'm lowering because I think the nine-dash line South China Sea issue before the UN arbitration will impact RCEP progress.

I find little news about this.  With 16 countries involved and so many huge issues yet to be addressed, I have strong doubts it will be completed anytime soon.  I recall that India held up for several years a major WTO treaty that had taken something like 20 years to negotiate; why would India act differently here?

Reducing from 75 last month, for passage of time. The next round starts 22 April in Perth, Australia, but it's worth remembering that negotiations have been in progress since November 2012. The article copied below is from the Indian perspective and shows there is still a long way to go.
may be somebody from 16 countries will discuss further (5-6 month to 2017 year). They discussed five years, they can negotiate additional 5 months too.
It appears that there remains a serious focus on completing this deal before the end of the year. Modifying up.
RCEP is currently in the process of being ratified by all countries involved.  See link for detail (limited) : http://www.nst.com.my/news/2016/03/131897/malaysia-benefit-tpp-rcep-and-ita-hsbc
Moving down from 85 to 74 based upon a couple comments.
If TPP made it through, I suppose anything can with all the distractions intelligent people have these days.
It's in their best interest not to show too much alignment with US foreign policy.

Any feedback is appreciate as I want to make sure I thinking of this correctly. (scope sensitive to the time for example) @morrell @einsteinjs @Khalid
--
There is a 0% probability the negotiations conclude by the original deadline in June. And, I estimate more than a 51% probability they are completed by December. 
Equal premise restated in the obverse:
100% probability they will not be completed by the deadline in June. And, I estimate less than a 49% probability they will fail to conclude by December.
Round 11's  5 day's worth of meetings and negotiations seems to have generated few headlines, and nearly no specifics.  To me, that means that they've got a long, long way to go.
lowering from 80 to 75% on India's concerns but I'm still optimistic the fear of failure (pain trade) is greater for India to defect from the process than compromise.

Reducing because India appears to have raised what I think is a new issue (easing of visa restrictions for service industries).  Potential for this to continue to slow things down.  Still general belief that it can get done in 2016.
The member nations are watching the US elections with horror and will want something they can count on.

"With the TPP becoming a reality, expediting RCEP is in our interest,"  Secretary (East) in the external affairs ministry Anil Wadhwa 
http://www.newkerala.com/news/2016/fullnews-22397.html

lowing from 99% on a the general concern negotiating with India
--
India's general disposition to trade may make them Insular to compromise [see link below].  They're not feeling the economic "pain" yet domestically but given a long-term outlook they'll be desperate for a regional export markets if they screw up this FTA opportunity.  That's sufficient to preclude defection from the process but it's roughly 20% less probable the RCEP will complete negotiates by the end of this year because everyone has to deal with Indian  : /
--
1/16 India * 3 parties being discriminated against = 18.75% membership headache  (  those being discriminated against include China, New Zealand, and Australia )
99% - 18.75 =80%
--
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/139295

Reducing from 90% a month ago. Although a meeting is currently being held in Brunei, there hasn't been any news so far as to what if any progress has been made.  It does appear that efforts are being made to conclude the agreement this year by proposing more meetings, and adding a forum where issues can be settled informally without waiting for one of the major settings. I still think it's very likely to happen with ten months to go but want to be nearer the consensus, especially as with additional meetings being suggested for August, October and December, negotiators clearly don't expect it to conclude by the "Final" scheduled meeting in June.

RCEP negotiations are taking place in Brunei this week.  CNBC article on India's interest in the RCEP.  India's exclusion from ASEAN has hopefully been excruciatingly painful so they don't squander this economic opportunity like usual.  New leadership, new day   : )

year.......export.....import.....trade deficit
2012........298.4.....	500.4........-202.0
2013........313.2.....	467.5........-154.3
2014........318.2.....	462.9........-144.7
2015........310.3.....	447.9........-137.6

I'm skeptical that any such negotiation will slip just 3 months past its initial schedule. If time were generally good, I'd be more positive. However, we might see Japan and China in a competitive devaluation this year, and an all-around tendency to pull-back into nationalist rhetoric rather than to engage. So, I'm going to buck the consensus a wee bit and give this even odds of ending this year. 
Could change, depending on the news that comes out from the talks being held in Brunei right now.
Will also change if the world economy sours: the sweeter things are, the more likely we see a deal.

When one hears the words "deflation", I'll bet you think 1930's depression in the U.S. and the misery in the Weimar Republic  (now Germany). 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Depression
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weimar_Republic

Highly probable, the negotiations have been ongoing for 4 years, most issues have already been discussed. The major players, ASEAN, Bharat, Zhongguo, etc all want a resolution this year. No one is in opposition.

Based on the little I know and @cdob63 blowing a hole in my thesis that deteriorating economic pressure would be a positive motivating factor.  I'll state a platitude: FTA are now used as much for environmental and human rights policy implementation than trade any more (that's what college course text books say any way ) so my rationalization for being overly optimistic at the moment is simply that global politics (save for China, which dooms the TPP) makes the RCEP more desirable since Chinese aggression within the region and economic decisions are coalescing support around China policy.  
--
As an aside, I was chatting with a friend in Australia yesterday & that was my take away.  Australia's dependence on China made them vulnerable so RCEP is good
predictions on this IFP are pretty thin so I'm not predicting as high as I otherwise would.  I think we'll know more after the 11th round to take place in Brunei February 15th-19th.
I'm adjusting to the 0% prediction right after mine

There doesn't seem to be any big barrier to this getting done but there is considerable economic change in the region and with so many parties there are lots of opportunities for one or more countries to slow peddle the negotiations if their negotiating position or what they want is in flux.

I always do what @cdob63 does, just not as well.  I didn't know that, "trade negotiations almost never depend on economics for their resolution. They are overwhelmingly political instead."  Thank you sir for that piece of knowledge, appreciated  : )
@josemi  makes a good point.... the economic environment is changing & I'm wondering if everyone is still confident in their forecast?
In the eve of a Chinese crisis an agreement that will foster the exit of funds from that economy is highly unlikely

I'll risk being overly confident on this since the final meeting is "planned" for September ( assuming ratification isn't required).  GATT took only 6 months and was fairly complex so I guess I'm willing to be overly confident that the parties want the deal completed in a timely manner so they will.

While there is significant pressure to reach an agreement there are several items that reduce my confidence agreement being reached. Most concerning is the lack of clarity on the negotiations. If the business community has concerns then that could delay negotiations. Additionally, there are a number of concerns regarding the relationships between the ASEAN countries (water and border disputes are common).

Forecast Upward: Smaller, more focused meetings for next round. Bodes well for some progress.
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/policy/rcep-agreement-eye-on-essential-pillars-meetings-to-be-smaller-and-more-focussed/articleshow/50750014.cms

Heads of state of participating countries are keen to see a deal. The completion of TPP has gives the negotiations a sense of urgency, and also frees negotiators working on both deals to focus on RCEP. The open issues don't present any problems that can't be overcome in 11 months.
16 parties and 4 rounds to complete in 11 months?  Too many contingencies, even if ratification is unnecessary for the question.

A lot of progress has been made in order to finalize this agreement.  Additionally, the upcoming 4 rounds are all going to be completed by mid to late 2016, with the 'final' one being in september.  This gives a lag time of nearly 3 months to finalize any last details and sign the agreement.  Given that ratification is NOT needed for this question, I feel comfortable placing it at a fairly high number.  That being said, I never trust international organizations fully to complete anything on time, making me unwilling to bump this higher.
I thought it might be useful to see how other treaties worked out in terms of time and number of members.
Conflicting interests here - getting China, Japan, Korea & India to agree is never easy - I note the 4 meetings set up already to advance this - will update as we get more information here.
China's instability will force its neighbors to seek security.
All that remains is the resolution details. (easier said than done.)
The commodity rout may be a driving force leading to an agreement on the RCEP in 2016.

Everybody is always optimistic about trade talks they're involved in.  Everybody is always wrong.  Sooner or later, talks are successful or abandoned, but in the meantime there is no theoretical limit on how long they can continue.  When folks say they're down to the last x% of issues, you know they're in for a long slog, because they've already dealt with the easy stuff, which is 100-x%.  Eventually, politics trumps economics one direction or the other.  Too soon to tell on this one yet, but let's give them the benefit of the doubt, in case it really is a benefit.

Four meetings scheduled this year, (Feb, April, June, September) with Sept marked "Final."  Having fourth meeting in Sept also allows possibility of fitting in another before the end of the year if necessary. Seems likely that the last bit of negotiations could be completed - intent was to finish by the end of 2015.  But - worth checking this after that Feb meeting (scheduled for 2/15 - 2/19 in Brunei).

Logic would say agreement should be finalized.... however, competition to devalue currencies to match the Yuan devaluation will poison the well. Human nature will overcome logic and even best longer term interests. Too bad.
It behooves all countries involved to complete the agreement because of the present economic situation across the world.

Original completion date of the agreement was set for end of 2015
Lack of transparency
India and Indonesia are the most conservative members in the agreement
TPP puts pressure on the agreement to get settled
IPR's and e-commerce are major factors holding up this agreement
There is some conflict between RCEP and TPP (http://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/publication/152753/reiwp-146.pdf).
In October 2015, it was reported that only 15% of the thousands of products being discussed remained to be agreed. However, these were "sensitive items".

The schedule is for an agreement to reached in September.  The crowd estimates are high, but there have been many previous delays.  I'm going to start with a 65% estimate, slightly increased for gaming.
Feb mtg next round with Post Sept wrap up after asean ministerial mtg .
Seems to be as on track as any such endeavour can be at this point, but a lot of stuff can go over the thing in a year.  One can pontificate with more confidence in maybe April.
